form.preferredDefinition: Standing height is measured from the top of the participant's head to his or her heels. Measured weight is assessed using a digital floor scale that should be calibrated daily using standardized weights, and a log of calibration results should be maintained. These measurements are taken among participants who are able to stand unassisted.

headerInstruction.text: Stature measurements are made with the head aligned in the Frankfort horizontal plane (Exhibit 2). The head is in the Frankfort plane when the horizontal line from the ear canal to the lower border of the orbit of the eye is parallel to the fl..TRUNCATED

Current Measured Weight Protocol: A digital scale or beam balance is used to weigh participants. Participants are asked to wear an examination gown and socks or light clothes without shoes. Only undergarments are worn beneath the gown. The procedures for obtaining the weight measurement are as follows: The examiner briefly informs the participant that his/her weight will be measured. Participants are asked to remove objects such as cell phones, wallets, and toys from their pockets. The health technician directs participants to stand in the center of the scale platform with hands at their sides and looking straight ahead. The weight measurement is recorded in kilograms or pounds. Special situations: Small children: Infants and toddlers who cannot stand alone on the scale will be weighed with an adult, with an infant's scale. If an adult is holding the child, then the adult guardian or the health technician will stand alone on the scale so the scale can be tared. This sets the scale readout to zero. The child is then handed to the adult and the child's weight is measured. If the participant is wearing a cast or medical prosthesis, make a note in the record of the location and place. If the participant wore street clothes instead of the examination gown, make a note of this in the record. It is acceptable for infants to wear diapers or underpants and a t-shirt.Participants should not be weighed if they are wearing shoes. Note that special consideration may be needed for participants whose weight exceeds the capacity of the study scale. For example, weight can be obtained using two portable scales: Have the participant stand with one foot on each portable scale. Combine the two results to approximate the weight. Record the weight. If the weight equals the capacity of both portable scales, note that the weight Equals Capacity (EC) of the scales. Record current weight in pounds or kilograms. Repeat weight measurement. (weight_instr_570101)
Record whether the participant is wearing a cast or prosthesis. (cast_or_medical_prosthesis)
If the participant is wearing one, record the location of a cast or medical prosthesis (cast_or_medical_prosthesis_location)
Record whether or not the participant is wearing street (as opposed to a gown) clothes during measurement. (street_clothes)

calculated BMI in kg/m2 (bmi__kilogram_per_squaremeter)
calculated BMI in lb/in2 (bmi__pound_per_squareinch)

Derivation of Body Mass Index (BMI): BMI calculations are recommended in children (2+ years) and adults, but some references suggest that the calculations are relevant from birth. Measurement Units Formula and Calculation Kilograms and meters (or centimeters) Formula: BMI = weight (kg) / [height (m)]2 With the metric system, the formula for BMI is weight in kilograms divided by height in meters squared. Since height is commonly measured in centimeters, divide height in centimeters by 100 to obtain height in meters. Example: Weight = 68 kg, Height= 165 cm (1.65 m) Calculation: 68/(1.65)2= 24.98 Pounds and inches : Formula: BMI = weight (lb) / [height (in)]2 x 703 Calculate BMI by dividing weight in pounds (lbs) by height in inches (in) squared and multiplying by a conversion factor of 703. Example: Weight = 150 lbs, Height = 5'5" (65") Calculation: [150 / (65)2] x 703 = 24.96Source: Centers for Disease Control and Preventio n website. Body Mass Index page. (bmi_570101)

Interpretation of BMI in Adults: The following categories are used to interpret BMI in both adult men and women (20 years old and older). Underweight : below 18.5 Normal weight: 18.524.9 Overweight: 2529.9 Obesity: 30 and aboveSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention website. Body Mass Index page. Interpretation of BMI in Children and Teens: BMI for children and teens is age and sexspecific, so it is often referred to as BMIforage. After calculating BMI, the BMI number should be plotted on the BMIforage growth chart (available for boys and girls, separately, from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention website) to obtain a percentile ranking. The following categories are used to interpret BMIforage in children and teens. Underweight: less than the 5th percentile Normal weight: 5th percentile to less than the 85th percentile Overweight: 85th to less than the 95th percentile Obesity: equal to or greater than the 95th percentile (interpretation_bmi)

protocol.preferredDefinition: Standing height is measured from the top of the participant's head to his or her heels. Measured weight is assessed using a digital floor scale that should be calibrated daily using standardized weights, and a log of calibration results should be maintained. These measurements are taken among participants who are able to stand unassisted.

form.longName: PhenX PX560301 - Duration Of Abstinence Alcohol
form.preferredDefinition: Measurement of recency of alcohol consumption.

headerInstruction.text: The next questions are about drinking alcohol. This includes coolers beer wine champagne liquor such as whiskey, rum, gin, vodka, scotch, or liqueurs and also any other type of alcohol.

question.questionText: How long has it been since you last had a drink of any kind of beer, wine, liquor, or cooler? (how_long_since_last_drink)
How long has it been since you last had a drink of any kind of beer, wine, liquor, or cooler? Units (how_long_since_last_drink_units)

protocol.preferredDefinition: Measurement of recency of alcohol consumption.

form.longName: PhenX PX570201 - Selfreport Of Human Immunodeficiency Virus Hiv Testing
form.preferredDefinition: The National HIV Behavioral Surveillance System (NHBS) survey began in 2003 to determine risk behavior and HIV testing experiences. NHBS is conducted in cities with a high incidence of AIDS with three groups of people: men who have sex with men (MSM), injection drug users (IDU), and heterosexuals at high risk of exposure to HIV infection. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) provides funding to state and local health departments to collect the information. This is an interviewer-administered protocol that gathers sensitive information.

headerInstruction.text: Below are a few questions about getting tested for HIV. Remember, an HIV test checks whether someone has the virus that causes AIDS.

module.longName: Self-report of Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) Testing
module.preferredDefinition: Self-report of Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) Testing

question.questionText: 1. Have you ever been tested for HIV? (tested_for_hiv)
If the answer to Q1 is NO = skip to Q4 If the answer to Q1 is Refused or Don't know, end the protocol: If the answer to Q1 is YES = go to Q2 and continue (directions_570201)
2. What month (112) did you have your most recent HIV test? (most_recent_hiv_test_month)
2a. What year did you have your most recent HIV test? (most_recent_hiv_test_year)
3. What was the result of your most recent HIV test? (most_recent_hiv_test_result)

INTERVIEWER INSTRUCTIONS: Refer to Q2. LAST HIV TEST WAS DONE (Check one): 1.) ? 12 months ago. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .[ ] End protocol 2.) > 12 months ago. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .[ ] Go to Q4 3.) Date of last test Don't know/Refused. . . .[ ] End protocol (interview_instru_570201)

4. I'm going to read you a list of reasons why some people have not been tested for HIV. Which of these best describes the most important reason you have not been tested for HIV in the past 12 months? (reason_not_tested_for_hiv)

validValue.meaningText: You think you are at low risk for HIV infection?
validValue.description: You think you are at low risk for HIV infection?

validValue.meaningText: You were afraid of finding out that you had HIV?
validValue.description: You were afraid of finding out that you had HIV?

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) provides funding to state and local health departments to collect the information. This is an interviewer-administered protocol that gathers sensitive information.
